metaphor.core: The simulated reality of 'The Matrix', where Morpheus teaches Neo to manipulate the environment by understanding its underlying code, serves as a metaphor for JSX. JSX is presented as the human-readable, declarative language (the 'what') for describing UI in React, which is then compiled into the machine-level `React.createElement` calls (the 'how') that React actually executes. This mirrors how Neo learns to 'see' the Matrix's code to understand and control its reality.

mapping.reactConcept: The browser's DOM, rendered and manipulated by React.
The React framework and the developer's understanding of its principles.
The underlying `React.createElement` function calls that React uses to build UI elements.
Manually writing `React.createElement` calls, which is verbose, hard to read, and error-prone for complex UIs.

mapping.fictionElement: Neo struggling with nested function calls / glitchy mess
mapping.reactConcept: The difficulty and error-proneness of writing complex UI structures directly with `React.createElement`.

mapping.fictionElement: Morpheus holding the spoon: 'Stop trying to build it. Just see the spoon.'
mapping.reactConcept: The declarative nature of JSX: focusing on *what* the UI should look like rather than *how* to build each element step-by-step.

mapping.fictionElement: Describing the street scene in human terms
mapping.reactConcept: Writing UI with JSX: an XML-like syntax embedded in JavaScript that is intuitive and mirrors HTML structure, making UI development more accessible.

mapping.fictionElement: Two Maps, One Destination (JSX and createElement being compiled to the same output)
mapping.reactConcept: JSX is syntactic sugar that transpiles (via Babel) into `React.createElement` calls; both achieve the same outcome but with different levels of developer experience.

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module introduces JSX through Neo entering 'The Construct' (React environment). It then exposes the pain of 'The Language of the Machine' (manual `React.createElement` calls). Morpheus's lesson to 'Stop Building the Spoon' leads to the revelation of JSX as a human-friendly declarative language. 'Two Maps, One Destination' compares JSX and its compiled output, and finally, Neo's 'I Know JSX' moment signifies mastery, seeing both the UI and the underlying code.

problems: Verbose and complex UI creation with raw `React.createElement` calls

chapters.title: Welcome to the Construct
chapters.focus: Introduces JSX as a declarative syntax for describing UI in React, hinting at its underlying compilation.

chapters.title: The Language of the Machine
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the anti-pattern: manually writing verbose and error-prone `React.createElement` calls for UI creation.

chapters.title: Stop Building the Spoon
chapters.focus: Explains JSX as the declarative, human-readable solution for UI description, abstracting away verbose function calls.

chapters.title: Two Maps, One Destination
chapters.focus: Compares JSX directly with its compiled `React.createElement` output, illustrating that JSX is syntactic sugar that produces the same machine code.

chapters.title: I Know JSX
chapters.focus: Summarizes the mastery of JSX, emphasizing its readability, maintainability, and declarative power in building complex React UIs.
